assignments.rationale: The 1579.94 cm⁻¹ peak closely matches the G band of sp2 carbon materials such as graphite and graphene, which is attributed to the E2g phonon at the Brillouin zone center. This band is a signature feature of graphitic carbon and is typically observed in the 1575–1585 cm⁻¹ range.
assignments.literature_reference: Ferrari & Robertson (2000). Interpretation of Raman spectra of disordered and amorphous carbon. Phys. Rev. B, 61(20), 14095–14107. https://doi.org/10.1103/PhysRevB.61.14095

assignments.rationale: Benzene and aromatic rings exhibit a strong Raman band near 1580 cm⁻¹ due to symmetric C=C stretching within the aromatic ring. This mode is prominent in pure benzene and related aromatic compounds.
assignments.literature_reference: Socrates, G. (2004). Infrared and Raman Characteristic Group Frequencies: Tables and Charts (3rd Ed.). Wiley.

assignments.rationale: Polyaromatic hydrocarbons such as naphthalene and anthracene display strong Raman bands in the 1570–1600 cm⁻¹ region, corresponding to aromatic C=C stretching. However, the intensity and exact position can vary with molecular structure and substitution.
assignments.literature_reference: Sadezky et al. (2005). Raman microspectroscopy of soot and related carbonaceous materials: Spectral analysis and structural information. Carbon, 43(8), 1731–1742. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.carbon.2005.02.018

summary.analysis_overview: The observed peak at 1579.94 cm⁻¹ with high intensity and moderate FWHM is characteristic of the G band in sp2 carbon materials, particularly graphite and graphene. This feature is a well-established marker for graphitic domains.
summary.key_literature_findings: Ferrari & Robertson (2000) and Sadezky et al. (2005) confirm the assignment of the G band in the 1575–1585 cm⁻¹ region for graphite and related materials. The RRUFF and NIST databases also list this frequency as the G band for sp2 carbon.
summary.alternative_considerations: Benzene and polyaromatic hydrocarbons also show strong bands near this region due to aromatic C=C stretching. However, their spectral context and band shapes differ, and the high intensity and FWHM observed here are more consistent with extended sp2 carbon networks than with discrete aromatic molecules.

references: Ferrari, A. C., & Robertson, J. (2000). Interpretation of Raman spectra of disordered and amorphous carbon. Physical Review B, 61(20), 14095–14107. https://doi.org/10.1103/PhysRevB.61.14095
Socrates, G. (2004). Infrared and Raman Characteristic Group Frequencies: Tables and Charts (3rd Ed.). Wiley.

Sadezky, A., Muckenhuber, H., Grothe, H., Niessner, R., & Pöschl, U. (2005). Raman microspectroscopy of soot and related carbonaceous materials: Spectral analysis and structural information. Carbon, 43(8), 1731–1742. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.carbon.2005.02.018

assignments.vibrational_mode: 2D (G' band) overtone of the D band (second-order two-phonon process)
assignments.rationale: The 2D band near 2670 cm⁻¹ is a well-established signature of graphitic carbon, particularly graphene and graphite. It arises from a second-order overtone of the D band and is prominent even in defect-free samples. The observed FWHM and high intensity are consistent with few-layer graphene or graphite.
assignments.literature_reference: Ferrari et al. (2006). 'Raman Spectrum of Graphene and Graphene Layers.' Physical Review Letters, 97(18), 187401. https://doi.org/10.1103/PhysRevLett.97.187401

assignments.vibrational_mode: 2D (G' band) overtone of the D band (second-order two-phonon process)
assignments.rationale: CNTs exhibit a strong 2D band in the 2650–2700 cm⁻¹ region, similar to graphite, due to their graphitic structure. The band shape and position can vary with tube diameter and chirality, but the assignment is less likely than graphite due to typical differences in FWHM and intensity.
assignments.literature_reference: Dresselhaus et al. (2010). 'Raman spectroscopy of carbon nanotubes.' Physics Reports, 409(2), 47-99. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.physrep.2004.02.006

assignments.vibrational_mode: Aromatic C–H stretching overtone or combination band
assignments.rationale: Some PAHs can show weak overtones or combination bands in the 2600–2700 cm⁻¹ region, but these are typically much weaker and broader than the observed peak, and rarely reach such high intensity.
assignments.literature_reference: Socrates, G. (2004). 'Infrared and Raman Characteristic Group Frequencies: Tables and Charts.' 3rd Edition, Wiley. (See Table 8.2, Aromatic Overtones)

summary.analysis_overview: The peak at 2670.19 cm⁻¹ with high intensity and moderate FWHM is characteristic of the 2D (G') band in graphitic carbon materials, particularly graphene and graphite. This band is a second-order overtone of the D band and is a key fingerprint for these materials.
summary.key_literature_findings: Ferrari et al. (2006) and the RRUFF/NIST databases consistently report the 2D band for graphite/graphene in the 2660–2700 cm⁻¹ region with similar intensity and FWHM. The band is less prominent in CNTs and PAHs, with differences in shape and intensity.
summary.alternative_considerations: While CNTs and PAHs can show features in this region, their Raman signatures differ in band shape, width, and intensity. CNTs typically have a broader or split 2D band due to tube diameter effects, and PAH overtones are much weaker, making them less likely assignments.

references: Ferrari, A. C., Meyer, J. C., Scardaci, V., Casiraghi, C., Lazzeri, M., Mauri, F., ... & Geim, A. K. (2006). Raman Spectrum of Graphene and Graphene Layers. Physical Review Letters, 97(18), 187401. https://doi.org/10.1103/PhysRevLett.97.187401
Dresselhaus, M. S., Jorio, A., Saito, R., & Dresselhaus, G. (2010). Raman spectroscopy of carbon nanotubes. Physics Reports, 409(2), 47-99. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.physrep.2004.02.006
Socrates, G. (2004). Infrared and Raman Characteristic Group Frequencies: Tables and Charts. 3rd Edition, Wiley.
